en: Formerly in the Prussian Royal Collection

Eukleia (labelled in the left field), bending profile to the right, with her right leg bent back, wearing a belted peplos, a short, high pony tail, hoop earrings, proffers a large box held in both hands; a low table; a sprig of vegetation; Eunomia (labelled), seated 3/4-view to the left on a rock, wearing a belted peplos, a sphendone, and hoop earrings, rests her left hand on a rock, and holds an indistinct bird (identified by Bhr [1993] as a nightingale) on her right hand; another sprig; a goose; a female figure standing 3/4-view to the left, wearing a belted peplos, and a sakkos, holds a plemmochoe and a fringed sash in her left hand, and reaches her right hand to the left; a kalathos; a female figure, Pa(i)dia (labelled), standing profile to the right, wearing a belted peplos, bends both arms to the right, holds a beaded necklace (?) in her lowered left hand, and a large box and a himation in her right hand; another female figure seated on the rocks 3/4-view to the left, wearing a belted, sleeveless chiton, raises an alabastron in her right hand, and rests her left hand on the rock, above a large box; a sash (?) hanging; a female figure, standing 3/4-view to the left, wearing a belted peplos, a sakkos (eroded), holds drapery or a fan (?) in her lowered right hand, and a plemmochoe and himation in her upraised left hand.

Hampe (123) suggested that Eukleia was shown here welcoming Eunomia into her cult with a gift; this suggestion is encouraged by Bhr's interpretation of Eunomia's bird as a nightingale, a symbol of (the welcoming into) society, for according to Aelian, NA 5.38, the nightingale sings more enthusiastically when (it has an audience) in society.

E. Bhr, CVA Mainz University 2 (1993) 45-47 pl. 27 (with previous
      bibliography).
Eunomia and Eukleia with Paidia and others
